channel.title: How to get rid of a nasty JFrame, or a client theme! :)

item.title: How to get rid of a nasty JFrame, or a client theme! :)
item.dc:creator: @Mod_Val Mod Val
item.description:
@Mod_Val wrote:

[center]It is NOT my fault if you fuck up your client; BACK IT UP.[/center]

Things needed:
Client that uses Gui for JFrame, or for the IP.
Notepad
client.java
Gui.java (nasty thing)
An IQ higher than 1
And copy, paste abilitys

Step 1:

Open up your client folder and make a new file called Ipset save it as a “.java” file.

Step 2:

Adding the code to the Ipset.java…

Add this code and I will explain it on the way.

First add this:

import javax.swing.*; import java.awt.*; import java.lang.String; import java.awt.event.*; import java.io.BufferedReader; import java.io.File; import java.io.FileOutputStream; import java.io.InputStreamReader; import java.io.IOException; import java.net.InetAddress; import java.net.URL; import java.util.ArrayList;
Just imports everything needed, although some of this probably isn’t needed.

Make a bit of room under that and add this:

public class Ipset extends client {

This starts our main class, this is where the coding starts.

Now, lets add this:

public static final String SERVERIP = "#.#.#.#"; // Ip to connect to.

This is the ip string, this is where you’d put a servers ip.

And close it with a:

}

File save, on to step 3.

Step 3:

Open up client.java and replace all (ctrl + h), “Gui.server” without the quotes. Replace it with this:

Ipset.SERVERIP

File save and compile, and you’re done! Simply in your run where it says,

.:Theme.jar Gui

Replace the “Gui” with Ipset. File save, and run it.

[center]What did we do!?!?!?![/center]

import javax.swing.;
import java.awt.;
import java.lang.String;
import java.awt.event.*;
import java.io.BufferedReader;
import java.io.File;
import java.io.FileOutputStream;
import java.io.InputStreamReader;
import java.io.IOException;
import java.net.InetAddress;
import java.net.URL;
import java.util.ArrayList;

public class Ipset extends client {

public static final String SERVERIP = “127.0.0.1”; // Ip to connect to.

}

Imported everything needed to use this code.

Started the class, enabling us to code even farther. This is basically like the main function need inorder to continue; more like the foundation to a building. Can’t start without it.

A string storing the IP.

Ends the class.

[center]FAQS[/center]
[center]Q: Do I have to name the file Ipset?

A: No, thats just the name that I chose. Just make sure that you rename the class too.

Q: Why doesn’t my client have a name?

A: Because the name is part of the JFrame Ill most likely fix this.[/center]

Val

Read full topic
item.source: How to get rid of a nasty JFrame, or a client theme! :)
